captions.text: MATT FARAH: Ah, the DeLorean.

The car that made
me love cars.

From its stainless steel
construction, Bugaro styling,

and role in one of my favorite
movie franchises of all time,
what's not to love?

Well, there is something
not to love, actually.
And that's the engine.

Because although it does
work, it is boring.

And I have been on a quest
to find a better,
faster, cool DeLorean.
So far, it's been my unicorn.

If you remember, last season on
Tuned, we tried to drive an

engine-swap DeLorean, and
it didn't go well.

That's when I got a call from
Stephen Wynne, who is the CEO

of the DeLorean Motor Company,
right here in Houston, Texas.

He says, Matt, come
drive my DeLorean.
It only has one moving part.

And that's what we're
here to do.

Because this is the
electric DeLorean.

With a 35-kilowatt hour electric
motor, it makes 250

horsepower and runs
on zero gas.

So today, I'm going to take it
for a ride and see if I can
finally have my cool DeLorean.

I'm Matt Farah, and
welcome to Tuned.

STEPHEN WYNNE: 200 feet
in each direction.

It's a 40,000-square-foot
warehouse.
MATT FARAH: Oh my god.
Show me the rest.

STEPHEN WYNNE: So there
are 2,850 parts
that go to a DeLorean.
MATT FARAH: OK.

STEPHEN WYNNE: And you will
see literally thousands of

each piece in here, depending
on what it goes to.

You see the engines
here to the right.
These are NOS crate engines.

There's probably about
75, 80 engines here.

Which is what we have left from
the original inventory.

MATT FARAH: So you literally
purchased the entire factory's
worth of inventory, right?
STEPHEN WYNNE: Yeah, yeah.
Quarter panels.

Then we've got glass and hoods
and fenders here to the right.

At the end of it, they just
had this freaky condition

where they had masses of
inventory that they normally
wouldn't have had.

And then they went into
receivership.

So we've been able to work with
this inventory for the

past 15 years, since
we acquired it.

MATT FARAH: There's got to
be 1,000 doors here.

STEPHEN WYNNE: There
is, actually, yeah.

MATT FARAH: Are there
1,000 doors here?

STEPHEN WYNNE: There's eight
pieces of stainless on the
exterior of the car.

And pretty well all of
it we've got, other
than the left fender.

And the left fender, we're
down to a handful.

So going forward, that is
something that we will
eventually have to reproduce.
There's two stories going on.

One is that they were always
stamped in batches.

And the next batch to stamp was
the left fender, and then
they went into receivership.
And they never got stamped.

MATT FARAH: So if I wanted a
left front fender, how much

more would it cost than
a right front fender?

STEPHEN WYNNE: Well, a right
fender retails for
about $800 or $900.

And a left fender, because
of the supply and
MATT FARAH: Oh, really?

Oh, so it's four times
the price, basically.

STEPHEN WYNNE: Yeah,
yeah, yeah.

MATT FARAH: I came here
to drive your
new electric DeLorean.
So why don't you show me that?
STEPHEN WYNNE: Sure.
Yeah.
Let's go check it out.

So what we have here is the
electric DeLorean, which we

unveiled to the market
last October.

The car has 35 kilowatts
of power on board.

It has a zero to 60 in sub-5
seconds and top speed of over
100 miles an hour.

It has a lithium ion phosphate
battery pack.

And this one here is a DC
motor, which has the

equivalent of about
250 horsepower.

We will be changing it when we
go to production, and it'll be
an AC motor.

The DC motor does not
have any regen.

So obviously, we want to have
regen, which will happen when
we go into production.
MATT FARAH: Sit in here.
It's mostly similar.
So let's start it.
It's now on.
OK.

And I've got a simple
knob here.

Just reverse, neutral, drive,
like a golf cart.

Switch it over to drive,
and we're off.
This is certainly strange.
It's pretty quiet in here.
It takes a while.

The DeLorean has a very firm
accelerator pedal, so I don't
really know how much to use.

But it's all sort of familiar
territory in here.

The gauges are exactly
what you'd
expect in a normal DeLorean.

There's a mock range gauge on
the right, because this is a
prototype car.
It's not fully done.

There's a battery gauge up
here, which is just a
mock-up right now.

There's an actual auxiliary
battery gauge down there,
which is functional.

But I have a full charge, so I
don't imagine I'll be running
out any time soon.

Torque my way out of corners
very nicely.

The electric motor in this car
makes 230 horsepower and 240

pounds of torque, which
is actually not bad.

It's almost twice the torque
the original car made and

about 100 horsepower more
than the original.

But it does carry around about
300 pounds of extra weight.

And you feel it through
the steering, if
not through the engine.

And if you thought the Camaro
required a gangsta lean

position, you've never
been in a DeLorean.

Because I feel like I'm in a
Formula One seat right now
with how far I'm laying down.

It's also a prototype, and
therefore it does not have air
conditioning.

So this tiny little window
here, that's all you get.

The good news is I can still
drive with the doors open if I

ever want a freshy
fresh breeze.

And actually, quite
prefer that.
This is better.
All right.
There's traffic coming.

I'm going to pull out in front
of traffic quickly.
Let's see.
That's floored.
Here we go.

That's 15, 20 mile an
hour, 50 there's 70.
Oh, so it goes.

It does get up and
go a little bit.

In a Tesla, you get that
really loud, pronounced
whirrrr, the Jetson's noise.

In this, there's
really nothing.

You don't hear a whole lot
of electric motor.

And we have a microphone
back there in the motor
compartment.

And I'm not really sure
it's picking it up.
Tom, is it picking it up?

We're not getting any real
sound back there either.

Now in this particular prototype
car, there are 13
battery packs.

There's some in the back,
where the motor is.

And there's some up front where
the gas tank used to be.

Now the good thing about that
is because this car was

originally a transaxle setup,
this tunnel here is completely
hollow and empty.

So in the production version,
they plan on filling this area

with batteries to give you a
potential 200-mile range,

versus about 100, which
is what you get with
this car as it sits.

Now something else Stephen told
me, that when they come

out with the production of this
car, they're going to

have a system in it called
reverse to grid.

So basically, let's say you're
charging the car at your
house, right?

Well, now there's a power
outage in your house.
Power goes out.
Thunderstorm, whatever.

You can reverse the flow and
power an average-size home for
three days using the car.
How cool is that?

When this car goes on sale,
hopefully in the middle of

next year, they're trying to
hit a target price of about
$95,000, including the car.

So given the fact that a really,
really nice DeLorean

with all new stuff in it is
about 50 grand, it's an extra

$40,000 for the electric
conversion.
It's nice to drive.

Hopefully they work out
everything they need to work

out in order to certify
it for road use.

Because I'd like to see
these driving around.
I think it's neat.

For LA traffic, it's a
great cruiser car.
You get more power than stock.
You don't use gas.

You spend a little more money
upfront, but you still have a

cool, classic car with an
electric conversion that just
fits the car well.
Well, I think we've found it.

A working, functional,
modified DeLorean.
And it's awesome.
I have had a great time today.
But there is one problem.

I like to drive, and 100 miles
isn't enough for me.

Fortunately, they have
another option.
And it's right here.

This flat-black, Jalopnik-themed
livery

DeLorean is a stage
three package.

And what you get for that is
heads, cams, headers, exhaust,

and a supercharger which feeds a
stock PRV engine five pounds

of boost, giving you
230 horsepower.

Although we didn't have time to
film it, I drove this car

earlier today, and it is
absolutely fantastic.

If you're a DeLorean owner or
prospective owner, I highly

recommend spending the
13 grand to get one.

I'd like to thank Stephen and
the guys for having me down
here at DMC Houston.
It's been a great day.

And we found a functional
Tuned DeLorean.

I'm Matt Farah, and thanks for
watching us on Tuned, right
here on the Drive network.

STEPHEN WYNNE: And we just
use an abrasive pad.

And just basically, all you
do is go with the grain.
Like that.
MATT FARAH: That's it?

STEPHEN WYNNE: Have
a try, see.
Just go with the grain.

MATT FARAH: Even an idiot
like me can do that.

STEPHEN WYNNE: And most people
are so frightened of the

stainless, thinking what do
I do if I scratch it?

MATT FARAH: So no wet sanding
or anything like that?
STEPHEN WYNNE: No, just dry.
MATT FARAH: This is a standard,
like almost a kitchen--

STEPHEN WYNNE: Well, the
grade designates the
coarseness of it.

Most common, you'll see
a green or the red,
and they're too soft.

comments.author: JAYCZero

comments.text:
+Andrew Curley Wow, your last paragraph is so full of mistakes.
First, yes, batteries with pre-charged electrolyte certainly do exist.  
Dead fluid can simply be pumped out and replaced with charged fluid in just 
a few minutes. The research was started at least four years ago by several 
different companies including BP.

No, hydrogen is not fuel.  It has a NEGATIVE energy balance, since it takes 
more electricity to create than it releases.  It isn't a substitute for 
electricity, it is a waste of electricity.

"High charge current" is exactly what I meant to say, referring to a high 
amount of current being used to charge.  Would you understand if I said 
"high charging current"?  And yes, using a high amount of charging current 
certainly does affect the speed of charging.  Tesla can provide over 150 
miles of range in less than 20 minutes at one of their Supercharger 
stations.

Tesla doesn't have a "proposal for swappable batteries".  They have already 
built them, and put on public exhibitions to show them off.  They work very 
well.

And your knowledge about supercapacitors is at least ten years obsolete.
comments.author: ralphinator2

comments.text:
+ralphinator2
I am not entirely sure where you got your education, but you had better ask 
for your money back.  Hydrogen is indeed a fuel, and its fuel value it much 
higher than any fossil fuel or hydrocarbon in existence per mass unit.  
Also, you had better learn about how a battery actually works.  The 
electrolytic solution in batteries do not contain any "pre-charge."  It is 
merely an ionizable solution to have the ability to transfer electrons from 
the anode to the cathode during electrochemical redox reactions.  Plus, I 
think you meant to say high voltage currents and not "high charge 
currents."  It does not mean the same thing, nor does the phrase make any 
sense.  A higher potential difference (i.e., voltage) can lessen the time 
required for recharging a battery, but not a high charge.  Charge can be 
thought of the actual number of electrons available to do work, so a "high 
charge current" would only account for the amount of distance you could 
potentially get out of the battery, not the speed of charging.  The only 
thing that I see in your post that would work is Tesla's proposal for 
swappable batteries.  There is still a problem with that... weight.  It is 
true that hydrogen would carry a substantial initial expense, but I would 
hardly call it a waste if it eliminates our dependence on fossil fuels.
comments.author: Andrew Curley

comments.text:
Hydrogen isn't fuel.  It releases energy when it bonds to oxygen, but first 
you have to create the free atoms by breaking them off of oxygen.  Subtract 
the heat and friction and storage and transporting and the billions of 
dollars of infrastructure and hydrogen is a big waste of energy, time, and 
money.
comments.author: ralphinator2

comments.text:
+Andrew Curley  Experiments are being done on batteries that accept high 
charging currents, other batteries with liquid electrolytes that can be 
pumped in pre-charged, and Tesla has swappable pre-charged packs than can 
be swapped in 5 minutes.
comments.author: ralphinator2

comments.text:
+ralphinator2
Supercapacitors are not well suited to this type of application.  They only 
hold approximately one-tenth of the energy that a battery can hold.  What 
this means is that although the battery may charge up in 15 minutes, you 
will probably only get around 20 miles to a charge if you're lucky.  
Capacitors are really designed to discharge their energy very quickly.  As 
for the experimental battery, could you elaborate on that?  I do not know 
the specifics of what you are referring to.  To have a vehicle that you can 
market to the public en masse, it needs to be able to travel long distances 
without refueling or a short refuel time.  Batteries in their current 
iteration do not fit the bill.  Hydrogen could take care of that with the 
proper infrastructure.
comments.author: Andrew Curley

comments.text:
+team0blackmanner
No problem.
comments.author: Andrew Curley

comments.text:
+Andrew Curley Super capacitors and some of the experimental batteries can 
be fully recharged in less than 15 minutes.
comments.author: ralphinator2

comments.text:
+team0blackmanner  Since electricity has to come from somewhere, you 
probably shouldn't waste it making hydrogen when you could just store it in 
batteries and super caps.
comments.author: ralphinator2

comments.text:
+team0blackmanner You can't beat physics.  When you make hydrogen, you 
break water molecules.  Hydrogen cars will always use more electricity than 
battery cars.
comments.author: ralphinator2

comments.text:
+Andrew Curley Thanks for the info. The last sentence made me LOL, so 
thanks for that too!
comments.author: LinusScrubTips

comments.text:
+team0blackmanner
Uranium is not actually the problem.  The problem is the plutonium, 
specifically Pu-239.  The best solution to the problem would be the liquid 
fluoride thorium reactor.  It can actually use up some of the waste 
plutonium.  Thorium is also much more abundant than uranium, it doesn't 
need enrichment to be used as fuel, and its waste products have a 
significantly shorter half-life.  Of course, the reason why they generally 
are not used in the U.S. is that thorium reactors do not produce weapons 
grade fissile material.  I suppose if we can't blow it up, we don't want it.
comments.author: Andrew Curley

comments.text:
+ralphinator2 Read? quote " just need a easy way to get hydrogen from 
water." by easy I mean't efficient. And obviously if we were using hydrogen 
as the main automotive fuel trucks might use it too. Even if trucks still 
used diesel, it would be nothing compared to all cars using fossil fuels. 
Also, electricity has to come from somewhere. Wind isn't efficient enough, 
water power isn't abundant enough, and solar is also not efficient enough. 
Coal pollutes the environment. Nuclear is really the only "clean" energy we 
have, but eventually we need to do something with the used uranium.
comments.author: LinusScrubTips

comments.text:
+ralphinator2
While it is true that hydrogen uses more electrical energy than just 
storing it in a battery, it has other advantages over batteries.  For 
example, what do you do if you have to drive over 200 miles?  You can not 
do that with electric vehicles.  Sure, you can just recharge them, but that 
usually takes several hours.  Hydrogen fueling stations could be a 
ubiquitous as a normal petrol station if the infrastructure was in place.  
That means you can fuel up and be back on the road without waiting.  Before 
either alternative becomes possible, however, there will need to be a major 
shift in general electricity generation.  With current technology, the best 
course would be nuclear energy.  It is clean and efficient if implemented 
properly.  That would generate enough electricity to make an abundance of 
hydrogen gas for use in fuel cells.
comments.author: Andrew Curley

comments.text:
+team0blackmanner  Hydrogen sucks.  Hydrogen cars use a lot more 
electricity than battery powered electric cars.  And they have to haul the 
hydrogen around in diesel trucks instead of beaming it over a wire.
comments.author: ralphinator2

comments.text:
+team0blackmanner
Getting hydrogen gas from water is easy, but it is just not cost effective 
enough yet to effectively out-compete fossil fuels.  You just run an 
electric current through water and that is it.  The problem is that it 
takes a fairly large amount of electricity, which unfortunately comes 
mainly from coal-fired plants.  Ironic, isn't it?  I still think that 
hydrogen fuel cells are one of the best ideas for an alternative fuel 
source.  To get enough electricity to generate the hydrogen gas, I 
personally think that nuclear energy would be the best way to achieve it 
currently.  Eventually, technology will improve enough that fossil fuels 
can be just a footnote in the history of the world.
comments.author: Andrew Curley

comments.text:
+Andrew Curley or just use hydrogen fuel cells. Seems more renewable than 
electric cars powered by coal power plants. just need a easy way to get 
hydrogen from water.
comments.author: LinusScrubTips

comments.text:
There is a great solution to your sound problem.  Use some speakers on the 
inside and outside.  You can run a program that monitors the engine load, 
rpm, and vehicle speed to reproduce the correct engine note through the 
speakers in real time.  As an added bonus, you can have different profiles 
for different people.  If you like the way a Ferrari sounds, use the 
Ferrari profile.  If you want it to sound like a high-rise cam V-8, no 
problem.  You could even put vibration motors in the body to give you the 
different feelings associated with the engine noise.  Think rumble pack.
comments.author: Andrew Curley

comments.author: IamMortui

comments.text:
The DMC12 has always been on my bucket list to drive.  Short of winning the 
lottery this car will always be a dream.  Growing up with Back to the 
Future movies and this cars rarity has made this something I've always 
wanted to own.  Its a beautiful car and I was so happy that someone managed 
to do what the DMC Motor Company has done to keep these icons on the road.  
I don't think an electric Delorean will be what owners will want.  The 
stage 3 however is something I would want.  However a engine swapped 
Delorean would never even cross my mind.  It would be like taking a Hemi 
Cuda and swapping a Chevy 350 in it.  However if I was to entertain the 
idea of a swapped Delorean I would look more at a LS engine.  Its a great 
car with iconic history.  I hope they never die and even almost 30 years 
ever time I see this car going down the road I can spot it a mile away and 
I weep for a car I have longed for since I was very young. ﻿
